On the brow of Mount Ida (a small mountain so named) we met with and engclged a young Greek as over guide, who told us he could come from Scio with an English lord, wbo lest the islarid sour days previous to our arrival in his felucca. This account excitedour curiosity very much, and we lost no time in hastening to the house where our countryrnan had resigned. In the sitting room we observed a marble recess, formerly, the old man told us, filled with books and papers, which were then in a large seaman chest in the closel: it was open, but we did not think ourselves justified in examining the contents. No man can read the preceding pleosing "traits" without feeling proud of him as a countryman. With respect to his love or pleasure, I do not assume a right to give an opinion. Lord Byron's character is worthy of his genius. To do good in the secret, and shun the world applause, is the worst testimony of a virtuous heart and self-approving conscience.

This account excited our curiosity very much, and we lost no time in the haslening house where our countryman had resided. We were kindly received by an old man, who conducted us over the mansion. It consisted of four apartments on the ground-floor — an entrance hall, a drawing-room, a silting parlor, and a bod-room, with a spacious closel annexed. They were all simply decorated: plain green stained walls, marble tables on either side, a large myrtle in the centre, and a small fountain beneath, which could be made to play through the branches by moving a spring fixed on the side of a small bronze Venus in a learning posture; a large couch or sofa completed the furniture. In this half stood half a dozen English cane chairs, and an empty book-case: there were no mirrors, nor a single painting. The bedchambor had more large maltress spread on the floor, with two stusfed colton quilts and a pillow — the co-mon bed throughout Greeco. In the sitting-room we observed amarble recess, formerly, the old man told us, filled with books and papers, which were then in a large seaman chest in the closet: it was open, but we did not think ourselves justified in examining the contents. On the tablet of the recess lay Voltaires, Shakspeare's, Boileau, and Rousseau works complete; Volney Ruins of Emplres; Zimmerman, in the German language; Klopstock's Messiah; Kolzebues novels; Schiller's play of the Robbers; Milton Paradise Last, an Italian edition, printed at Parma in 1810; several small pamphlets from the Greek press at Constantinople, much torn, but no English hook of any description. Most of these books were filled with marriage notes, written with a pencil, in Italian and Latin. The Messiah was literally scribbled all over, and marked with slips of paper, on which also were romarks.
The old rnan said :"The lord had been reading these books lhe evening before he sailed, and forgot to place them with others; but," said he ,"there thoy must lie until his return; for he is so particular, that were I to move one thing without orders, be would frown upon me for a week together; he is otherwise very good. The appearance of the house was externally pleasing. The portico in front was sifty pac es long and fourteen broad, and the fluted marble pillars with black paint and fret-work cornices ,( as just is now customary in Grecian architecture ,) were considerably higher than the roof. The roof, surrounded by a light stone balustradc, was covered by a fine Turkish carpet, beneath an awning of strong coarse linen. Most of the house-lops are also furnished, as upon them, the Greeks pass their evenings in smoking, dr inking light wines, such as "lachryrna Christi", eating fruit, and enjoying the ovening breeze.
On the left hand as we entered the house, a small streamlet glided away, grapes, oranges and limes were clustering together on its borderf, and under the shade of two large myrtle houses, a marble seat with an ornamental wooden back was placed, on which we were tol d, the lord passed many of his evenings and nights till twelve ooclock, rooding, writing, and talking to himself. "I suppose she," said the old man ,"praying" for he was very donut ," and always attended our church twice a week, besides Sundays."
The view from this seat was what may be termed "a bird-eye view". A line of rich yellowards led the eye to Mount Calcla, covered with olive and myrtle treef in bloom, and on the suminit of which an ancient Greek temple appeared in the majestic decoy. A small stream issuing from the ruins descended in broken cascades, until it was lost in the wood near the mountain base. Tho fea smaoth as glass, and an borizon unshadowed by a single cloud, termiriates the view in front; and a little on the left, through a vista of lofty chesnut and plumtrees, several small islands were distinctly observed, studding the light blue wave with spots of emerald green. I seldom enjoyed a lot more than I did this; but our enquiries were frultless as to the name of the person who had resided in this romantic solilude: none knew his name but Domlnick, his banker, who had agreed to Canada. "The Armenian," said our conductor ," could tell, bvt. I am sure he will not ,"—"And cannot you tell, old friend ?" said I ,"If I want," said he ," I dare not ." We had not time to visit the Armenian, but on our return to the town we learnt several particulars of the isolated lard. He had portioned eight young girls when he was last upon the island, and even danced with them at the nuptial feast. He gave a cold cow to one man, horses to others, and cotton and silk to the girls who live by weaving these articles. He also bought a new boat for a fatherman who had lost his own in a gale, and he often gave Greek Testaments to the poor children. In short, he appeared to us, from all we collected, to have been a very eccentric arid benevolent character. One circumstance we learnt, which our old friend at the cottage ought to be proper not to disclose. He had a most beautiful daughter, with whom the lord was often seen walking on the seashore, and he had bought her a piano-forte, and taught her himself the use of it.
Such was the information with which we departed from the peaceful side of MityIenc; our imaginations all on the rack, guessing who this rambler in Greece could be. Hc had more money it was evident: he had a philanthropy of disposition, and all those activities which inark peculiar genius. ct: Arrived at Palermo, all our doubts were difpelled. Falling in the company with Mr. FOSTER, the architect, a pupil of WYATTLES, who had been travelling in Egypt and Greece ,"The individual," said to be ," About whom you are so anxious, is Lord Byron; I met him in my travelson, the island of Tenedos, and I also visited him at MityIene." We had never then heard of his lordship fame, as we had been some years from home; but "Childe Harolde" being put into our hands, we recognized the recluse of Calcla on a very page. Deeply did we regret not having been more curious in our research at the cottage, but we consoled ourselves with the idea of returning to Milylene on some future day; but to me that day will never return. I make this statement, believing it is not quite unintcresting, and in justice to his lordships good name, which has been grossly slandered. He has been described as an unfeoling disposition, averse to associating with human nature, or contributing to its diary way to sooth its sorrows, or add to its pleasures. The fact is directly the reverse, as may be plainly gathered from these little coincidences. All the finer foelings of the heart, so elegantly depicted in his lordship poems, seem to have their soul in his bosom. Tenderness, sympathy, and charity appear to guide all his actions: and his courting the repose of solitude is an additional reason for marking him as a beginning on whose heart, Religion bath sells her seal, and over whose head Bencvolence hath throwri her money. No man can read the preceding pleasing "traits" without feeling proud of him as a countryman. With respect to his loves or pleasures, I do not assume the right to give an opinion. Reparts are ever to be received with caution, particularly when directed against man moral integrily; and he wbo dares juftify himself before that awsul tribunal which will appear, alone may censure the errors of a fellow-rnortal. Lord Byron's character is the warmth of his genius. To do good in fact, and shun the world applause, is the surest testimony of a virtuous heart and self-approving conscience.
THE END!

This account excited our curiosity very much, and we lost no time in hastening to the house where our countryman had resided. We were kindly received by an old man, who conducted us over the mansion. The bedchamber had merely a large mattress spread on the floor, with two stuffed cotton quilts arid a pillow — the common bed throughout Greece. In the sitting-room we observed a marble recess. formerly, the old man told us, filled with books and papers, which were then in a large seainan chest in the closet: it was open, but we did not think ourselves justified in examining the contents. The appearance of the hand used externally was playing. nian," said our conductor ,"could tell, but I am sure he will not ,","And cannot you tell an old friend?" said I ,"If I can" said he ,"I dare not." We had a time to visit the Armenian, bvl on our return to the town we learnt several particulars of being isolated lord. In short, he appeared to us, from all we collected, to have been a very eccentric and benevolentchcler. One circumstance we learnt, which our old friend at the cottage thought proper not to disclose. We had never then heard of his lordship fame, as we had been some years from home; but "Chied Harolde" being put into our hands, we recognized the recluse of Calcla on every page. Deeply did we regret not having been more curious in our research at the stage, but we consoled ourselves with the idea of returning to Mitylene on some future day; but to me that day will never return. I make this statement, believing it is not quite uninteresting, and in justice to his lordships, a good crime, which has been grossly slandered. He has been described as of an unfeeling disposition, averse to associating with human nature, or contributing in any way to sooth its sorrows, or add to its pleasures. The fact is directly the reverse, as only be plairily gathered from these little anecdotes. I have finer feelings of the heart, so elegantly depicled in his lordship poems, seem to have their seat in his bosom. Tenderness, sympatby, and Charily appeclr to guide all his actions: and his courting the repose of solitude is an additional reason for rnarking hirn as a being on whose heart religion hath sct her seal, and ouer whose hecld Benevolcnce hatbthrown her mant le. No man can read the preceding pleafing "traits" without feeling proud of him as a countryman. With respect to his loves or pleasures, I do not assume the right to give an opinion. Reports are ever to be received with caution, particularly when directed against man moral integrity; and he who dares justify himself before the awful tribunal where all must appear, alone may censure the errors of a fellow-mortal. Lord Byrori's character is worthy of his genius. To do goad in secret, and shun the world applause, is the surest testimony of a virtuous heart and self-approving c conscience.

On the brow of Mount Ido (a small mountain so named) we met with and engaged a young Greek as our guide, who told us he had come from Sclo with an English lard, but left the field four days previous to our arrival in his felucca. This account excited our curiosity very much and welost no time in hastening to the house where our countryman had resided. We were kindly received by an old man, who conducted us over the mansion. The appearance of the house was externally pleasing. The view from this seat was what may be termed "a bird-eye view ." Deeply did we regret not having been more ourious in our research at the cottage, but we cansoled ourselves with the idea of returning to Mitylene on some future day; but to me that day will never return n. being proud of him as a countryman. With respect to his love or pleasures, I do not assume the right to give an opinion. I make this statement, believing it is not quite uninteresting, and in justice to his lordships good name, which has been grossly slandered. He has been described as a clri unfeeling disposition, averse to associating with human nature, or contributing in any way to sooth its sorrows, or add to its pleasures. The fact is directly reverse, as may be plainly gathered from these little anecdotes. All the finer feelings of the heart, so elegantly depicted in his lordship poems, seem to have their seat in his home. Tenderness, sympathy, and charity appear to guide all his actions: and his courting the purpose of solitude is an additional reason for marking him as a being on whose heart religion hath set her seal, and over whose head Benevolence bath thrown her mantle. No man can read the preceding pleasing "traits" without feeling proud of him as a countryman. With respect to his love or pleasures, I do not assume a right to give an opinion. Reports are evor to be received with caution, particularly when dlrected against man moral integrity; and he who dares justify himself before that awful tribunal where all must appear, alono may ensure the error of a fellow-morla. Lord Byron's character is worthy of his genius. To do good in secret, and shun the world applause, is the surest testimony of a virtue, art and self-approving coriscience.

No man can read the preceding pleasing "traits" without feeling proud of him as a countrymari. With respect to his love or pleasures, I do not assume a right to give an opinion. ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRONS RESIDENCE, &c.
"The world was all before him, where to choose his place of rest, and Providence his guide ."
IN Sailjng through the Grecian Arohipelago, on board one of bis Majesty vesself, in the year 1812, we went into the harbour of Mitylene, on the island of that name. The beauty of this place, and the certain supply of cattle and vegetables always to be had there, induce many British vessels to visit it—both men of war and merchantmen; and though it lies rothor out of the traok for ships baund to Smyrna, its bounties completely repay sor the devicltian of a voyage. We landed; as usual, at the bottom of the bay, and whilst the men were employed in watering, and the purser bargaining for a cattlo with the natives, the clergyman and myself took a ramble to the cave called Homer's School, and other places where we had been before. On the brow of Mount Ida (a small mountain named ). we met with and engaged a young Greek as our guide, who told us he had come from Scio with an English lard, who left the island four days previous to our arrival in his felucca. "He engaged me as a pilot," said the Greek ," and would have taken me with him; but I did not choose to quit Mitylerie, where I am likely to get married. He was an odd, but a very good man. The cottage over the hill, facing the river, belongs to him, and he has left an old man in charge of it: be given Dominick, the wine-trader, fix hundred zechines for it ,( about L 250 English currency ,) arid has resided there about fourteen months, though not constantly; for he sails in his felucca very often to the different islands ."
This account execited our euriosity very much, and we lost no time in hastening to the house where our countryman had a residence. We were kindly received by an old man, who conducted us over the mansion. It consisted of four apartments on the ground-floar — an entrance hall, a drawing-room, a sitting parlour, and a bed-roorn, with a spacious closet repaired. They were all simply decorated: plain glazed walls, marble tables on either side, a large myrtle in the centre, and a small fountain beneclth, which could be made to play through the branches by moving a spring fixed on the side of a small hronze Venus iri, a loaning posture; a largo couch or sofa completed the furniture. In the hall stood half a dozen English cane chairs, and an empty bookcase: there were no mirrors, nor a single painting. The bedchamher had merely a large mattress spread from the floar, with two stvffed cotton quilts and a pillow — the common hand throughout Greece. In the sitting-room we observed an inarble reeess, formerly, the old man told us, filled with books and papers, which were then in a large seaman chest in the closct: it was open, but we did not think ourselves justified in examining the contents. On the tahlet of the recess lay VoItaires, Shakspeare's, Boileau, and Roussoau works eomplete; Volncy Ruins of Emplres; Zimmerman, in the German language; Klopstock's Messiah; Kotzebues novels; Schiller'splay of the Robbers; Miltans Paradise Lost, an Italion edition, printed at Parma in 1810; several small pampblets from the Greek press at Constantino Most of these books were filled with marginal notes, written with a pencil, in Italian and Latin. The Messiah was literally scribbled all over, and worked with a pile of paper, on which also were reinarks.
The old man said :"The lord had been reading these books the evening before he sailed, and forgot to place them with others; but," said he ,"there they must lie until his return; forhe is so particular, that were I to move one thing without orders, which would frown upon me for a week together; he always was very good. I once did him a service; and I have the produce of this form for the trouble of taking care of it, except twenty zechines which I pay to an aged Armenian who resides in a small cottage in the wood, and whom the lord brought here from Adrianople; I don't know for what reason ."
The appearance of the house was externally pleasing. The porlico in front was fifty paces long and fourteen broad, and the slated marble pilars with black plinths and fret-work cornices ,( as it is now customary in Grecian architecture ,) were considerably higher than the roof. This roof, surrounded by a light stone ablustrcle, was covered by a firie Turkey carpet, beneath an awning of a strong coarse lineri. Most of the house-tops are thus finished, as upon them, the Greeks pass their evenings in smoking, drinking eight wines, such as "lachryma Christian", eating fruit, and enjoying the evening breeze.
On the left hand as we entered the house, a small ftreamlet glided away, grapes, oranges and limes were clustering together on its borders, and under the shade of two large myrtle bushes, a marble seat with an ornamental wooden back was placed, on which we were lold, the lord passed many of his evenings and nights till twelve clocks, reading, writing, and lalking to the bimseif. "I suppose" said the old mon ,"playing" for he was very devout ,"and always attended our church twice a week, besides Sundays ."
The view from this seat was what may be termed "a bird-eye view ." A line of rich vineyards led the eye to Mount Calcla, covered with olive and myrtle rose iri bloom, and on the summit of which an ancient Greek temple appeared in majestic decay. A small stream issuing from the ruins descended into broken cascades, until it was lost in the woods near the mountain base. The sea smooth os glass, and an horizon unsbcladed by a single cloud, terminates the view in front; and a little on the left, through a vista of lofty chesnut and palm-trees, several single islands were distinctly observed, standing the light blue wave with spots of em erald green. I seldom enjoyed a view more than I did this; but our enquiries were fruitless as to the name of the person who had resided in this romantic solitude: none knew his name but Dominick, his banker, who had gone to Canada. "The Armenian" said our conductor ,"could tell, but I am sure he will not ,","And carinot to tell, old friend ?" said I ,"If I can," sclid he ,"I daro not". We had not time to visit the Armenian, but on our return to the town we learnt several particulars of the isolated lord. He had portioned eight young girls when he was last upon the island, and even drew them at the nuptial feast. He gave a cow to one inan, horses to others, and cotton and silk to the girls who live by weaving these articles. He also bought a new boat for a fisberman who had lost his own land, a gale, and he often gave Greek Testaments to the poor children. In short, he appeared to us, from all we collected, to have been a very eccentric and excellent character. The divorce circumstance we learnt, which our old friend at the cottage thought proper not to disclose. He had a most beautiful daughter, with whom the lord was often seen walking on the seashore, and he had bought her a piano-forte, and taught her himself the use of it.
Such will the information with which we departed from the peaceful isle of Mitylene; our imaginations all on the rack, guessing who this rambler in Greece could be. He had money. It was evidence: he had a philarithropy of dispasitiori, and all those eccentricities which mark peculiar gonius. ct: Arrived at Palermo, all our doubts were dispelled. Falling in company with Mr. FOSTER, the architect, a pupil of WYATTLES, who had been travelling in Egypt and Greece ,"The individual," said he ,"about whom you are so anxious, just Lord Byron; I met him on my travels on the island of Tenedos, and I also visited him at Mitylerie." We had never then heard of his lordshlps fame, if we had been some years from home; but "Childe Harolde" being put into our hands, we recognized the recluse of Calcla on every page. Deeply did we regret riot having been more curious in our research into the cottage, but we consoled ourselves with the idea of returning to Mitylone on some future day; but to me that day will never relurn. I make this statement, believing it is not quite interesting, and in justice to his lordships good name, which has been grossly slaridered. He has been desoribed of an unfeelingdisposition, averse to asso-
calculating with human nature, or contributing in any way to foot its sorrows, or adding to its pleasures. The fact is directly to reverse, as may both only gathered from these little anecdotes. All the finer feelings of a black heart, so elegantly depicted in his lordship poems, seems to have their seat in his bosoin. Tenderness, sympathy, and charity appear to guide all his actions: arid his courting the reposo of solitude is an additional reason sor marking a hirn as a boing on whose heart religion hath set her seal, and over whose head Benevolenoe hath thrown her a mole. No reason can read the preceding pleasing "traits" without feeling proud of him as a countryman. With respect to his love or pleasures, I do not assume the right to give an opinion. Reports are ever to be received with cautiori, parlicularly when directed against man moral integrity; and he who dares juslify himself before that awful tribunal where all must appear, alone may censure the errors of a fellow-mortol. Lord Byron's character is worthy of his genius s. To do good in secret, and shuri the world applause, if the surest testimony of a virtuous heartand self-cleaning conscience.
